mdRecord.dcterms:title: Carrel 4-9, upper shelf|front edge
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Donohue, Liam Patrick [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Tibetan script; the following information provided by Nawang Thokmey, Research Librarian for Tibetan/Buddhism/Contemplative Studies at UVA: the graffiti here includes the date 2017-09-13, and a passage attributed from a text called “sa skya legs bshad” — The Elegant Sayings of Sakya Paṇḍita, by Sakya Pandita Kunga Gyaltsen (1182–1251), with the passage translating to: Even if one is to die the next morning, today one must study. Though one may not become a sage in this life, Knowledge is safely deposited for future lives, Just as riches safely deposited can later be reclaimed. translation in this book: https://search.lib.virginia.edu/catalog/u4354337 [work]
Student graffiti art and messages inscribed on carrel walls in the new stacks, Alderman Library, University of Virginia, prior to the renovation of the building, 2020-2023. [host]
mdRecord.dcterms:subject: Tibetan literature
mdRecord.dcterms:spatial: University of Virginia. Library. New Stacks. Charlottesville, Virginia, United States
